section.title: Present perfect continuous and Present perfect simple
section.sectiontitle: In many cases we can use the Present perfect continuous and Present perfect simple with for and since with no real difference in meaning.
section.text1a: I've been living in this house for over a year.
section.text2a: I've lived in this house for over a year.
section.sectiontitle2: We cannot use the Present perfect continuous if a verb describes a state (e.g. like, love, be, have, know, see, believe, own).
section.text3: <FONT COLOR='#FC214C'>NOT</FONT>: They've been knowing each other for more than fifty years.
section.text3a: They've known each other for more than fifty years.
section.text4: <FONT COLOR='#FC214C'>NOT</FONT>: He's been having his car since 2006.
